citation.article-title: Spiroplasma chrysopicola sp. nov., Spiroplasma gladiatoris sp. nov., Spiroplasma helicoidis sp. nov., and Spiroplasma tabanidicola sp. nov. from tabanid (Diptera: Tabanidae) flies.

p.s: Description of Spiroplasma chrysopicola sp. nov.
Spiroplasma chrysopicola (chry.so.pi.'co.la. Gr. n.Chrysops, a genus of deer-flies in the Tabanidae L. v. colo, to inhabit; N. L. adj. chrysopicola, inhabiting Chrysops spp.)
Cells are filamentous, helical, and motile and lack a cell wall.
Colonies on solid medium containing 2.25% Noble agar have dense centers and smooth edges (a "fried-egg" appearance) and do not have satellites.
Cholesterol or serum is required for growth.
The temperature range for growth is 10 to 32°C.
Optimum growth occurs at 30°C, and the doubling time at 30°C is 6.4 h.
Serologically distinct from other established Spiroplasma species and putative groups.
Isolated from the gut of a deerfly (Chlysops sp.).
Pathogenicity for insects has not been determined.
The guanine-plus-cytosine content of the DNA is 30 ± 1 mol%, as determined by the buoyant density method.
The type strain is DF-1 (= ATCC 43209).
